definitions.definition: Firmly or securely fixed in place; stable .
examples: That rope is dangerously loose. Make it fast !

definitions.definition: Firm against attack; fortified by nature or art; impregnable; strong.
Steadfast , with unwavering feeling. (Now mostly in set phrases like fast friend(s) .)
Moving with great speed, or capable of doing so; swift , rapid .
examples: I am going to buy a fast car.

subdefinitions.definition: Having a kinetic energy between 1 million and 20 million electron volts ; often used to describe the energy state of free neutrons at the moment of their release by a nuclear fission or nuclear fusion reaction (i.e., before the neutrons have been slowed down by anything).
examples: Plutonium-240 has a much higher fission cross-section for fast neutrons than for thermal neutrons.

definitions.definition: Of a place, characterised by business, hustle and bustle, etc.
Causing unusual rapidity of play or action.
examples: a fast racket, or tennis court

definitions.definition: Able to transfer data in a short period of time .
definitions.label_groups: computing , of a piece of hardware

definitions.definition: Deep or sound (of sleep); fast asleep (of people).
Not running or fading when subjected to detrimental conditions such as wetness or intense light ; permanent .
examples: All the washing has come out pink. That red tee-shirt was not fast .

definitions.definition: Having an extravagant lifestyle or immoral habits.
Uncharacteristically mature or promiscuous for one's age.
labels: of a girl or young woman
definitions.label_groups: offensive , vernacular , dated , of a girl or young woman

definitions.definition: Ahead of the correct time or schedule .
examples: There must be something wrong with the hall clock. It is always fast .

definitions.definition: More sensitive to light than average .

main_definition: ( dated ) Firmly or securely fixed in place; stable . [from 9th c.]
secondary_definitions: Firm against attack; fortified by nature or art; impregnable; strong.
( of people ) Steadfast , with unwavering feeling. (Now mostly in set phrases like fast friend(s) .) [from 10th c.]
Moving with great speed, or capable of doing so; swift , rapid . [from 14th c.]
Of a place, characterised by business, hustle and bustle, etc.
Causing unusual rapidity of play or action.
( computing , of a piece of hardware ) Able to transfer data in a short period of time .
Deep or sound (of sleep); fast asleep (of people). [16th–19th c.]
( of dyes or colours ) Not running or fading when subjected to detrimental conditions such as wetness or intense light ; permanent . [from 17th c.]
( dated ) Having an extravagant lifestyle or immoral habits. [from 18th c.]
( offensive , vernacular , dated , of a girl or young woman ) Uncharacteristically mature or promiscuous for one's age.
Ahead of the correct time or schedule . [from 19th c.]
( of photographic film ) More sensitive to light than average . [from 20th c.]
